attributes.title: Ethiopian Electric Power HQ Building, Ethiopia

body.value:
• Build an energy-efficient and sustainable green main office building for Ethiopian Electric Power (EEP) situated in Addis Ababa's financial district
  • The building will cover a total area of 20,792 square metres and a total built-up area of 197,800 square metres
  • When completed, it will have a total floor area of 208,724 square metres and a height of 345.5 metres
  • The building will have 62 floors and the main components of the works are as follows:
    o Basements 1-3: Parking spaces, MEP Rooms
       Podium Levels:
    o Ground Floor: EEP Office Lobby, Commercial Offices Lobby, Retail Spaces, services
    o First Floor: Retail Spaces, services
    o Tower levels 1 to 55: Office spaces, sky gardens, services
    o Tower level 56: Sky Garden, Technical Floor
    o Tower level 57: Restaurant
  • This project will be carried out under an EPC contract and is expected to be completed in four years
  • Dar al-Handasah is the consultant for design and construction supervision
  • EEP is looking at various financing options to cover the cost of the construction  and once the bidding process is completed, the total cost of the construction will be announced

attributes.title: Deepwater Tano Cape Three Points (DWT/CTP), Ghana

body.value:
Pecan Energies has a 50 per cent  interest in the Deepwater Tano Cape Three Points block (DWT/CTP), covering approximately 2,010 square kilometres in a prolific petroleum region approximately 115 kilometres offshore Ghana. Partners in the DWT/CTP block include: 

  • Lukoil Overseas Ghana Tano Limited, 38 per cent
  • Fueltrade Limited 2%
  • Ghana National Petroleum Corporation, 10%

Source: Pecan Energies 

 

  • Location: Deepwater Tano/Cape Three Points (DWT/CTP) block, offshore Ghana
  • Water Depth: ~2,400 meters
  • Reserves Estimate: 334 million barrels of recoverable oil
  • Plateau Production Target: 110,000 barrels of oil per day (b/d)
  • Development Status: Pre-development / Early development planning

Scope of Work

Development Concept:

  • FPSO Unit:
    • A single Floating Production, Storage, and Offloading (FPSO) vessel to handle production, processing, and offloading of crude oil.
    • Topsides will include oil processing, gas compression, water injection, and utilities systems.
  • Subsea Production System:
    • Fully subsea field development with tiebacks to the FPSO.
    • Use of dynamic risers, umbilicals, manifolds, and flowlines for well connection.

Drilling Program:

  • Total Wells: Up to 26 subsea wells.
  • 14 production wells: Horizontal advanced oil wells targeting peak productivity.
  • 12 injection wells: Alternating water and gas injection (WAG) wells for pressure maintenance and enhanced oil recovery.

Artificial Lift:

  • Use of multiphase pumps to enable artificial lift and increase oil recovery efficiency.

attributes.content: Resource Potential:Recoverable Resources of 377 Bcf gross / 75.4 Bcf net (2C Resources)1 in the TE-5 Horst gas discovery, sub-salt Triassic TAGI reservoirInterests:Mana Energy (Operator) 55%Sound Energy 20%ONHYM 25%Future DevelopmentsPotential capacity to meet gas demand in a phased manner with Phase I being the implementation of a micro LNG development scheme and Phase II being the development of a larger scale central processing facility (CPF) and gas export pipeline.Phase 1

body.value:
Resource Potential:

Recoverable Resources of 377 Bcf gross / 75.4 Bcf net (2C Resources)1 in the TE-5 Horst gas discovery, sub-salt Triassic TAGI reservoir

Interests:

  • Mana Energy (Operator) 55%
  • Sound Energy 20%
  • ONHYM 25%

Future Developments

Potential capacity to meet gas demand in a phased manner with Phase I being the implementation of a micro LNG development scheme and Phase II being the development of a larger scale central processing facility (CPF) and gas export pipeline. 

Phase 1

Micro LNG Development

Deployment of field gas treatment, processing, liquefaction and storage facilities to deliver mobile LNG to buyer at site. 

Phase 2

Tendrara TE-5 Development

Gas as a transition fuel flowing to the GME pipeline

  • 20 inch, 120km Tendrara Gas Export Pipeline (TGEP):
  • Tie-in to existing GME pipeline (Station M04): FEED completed by Metragaz (EMPL operator)
  • FEED completed by Enags Consortium for a 70 mmscf/d raw gas processing capacity Central Processing Facility (CPF)
  • Gas Sales Agreement (GSA) with ONEE (Office National de lElectricite et de lEau potable) signed November 2021 for domestic power plants for gas-to-power generation (transit via GME line), minimum volume of 0.3 bcm/year
  • Six horizontal wells planned for First Gas (Phase 2)

Source: Sound Energy

• Location: Offshore Nigeria, Oil Mining Lease (OML) 112
  • Operatorship: Amni International Petroleum Development Company Limited (60%)
  • Partner: TotalEnergies E&P Nigeria Limited (40%)
  • Discovery Year: 1973
  • Production Start Year: 1996
  • Project Status: Operating

Scope of Work

Field Development: 

  • Wells: Drilling of six wells
  • Facilities: Construction of a primary gas treatment facility
  • Pipeline: Installation of a gas evacuation pipeline

Infrastructure:

  • Gas Processing Plant: Design and construction of a facility to process produced gas
  • Export Pipeline: Development of infrastructure to transport processed gas to market

Production and Reserves

Gas Production: Approximately 62.61 million cubic meters per year (as of 2015)

Oil Production: Approximately 3.45 million barrels per year (as of 2023)

Condensate Production: No condensate production reported in recent years

Investment and Development

Estimated Investment: Over $1 billion

Development Focus: Initiating gas production and expanding field infrastructure

attributes.content: Location: Offshore Nigeria, within OML 118, approximately 120 km from the Niger DeltaOperator: Shell Nigeria Exploration and Production Company (SNEPCo)Partners: ExxonMobil (20%), TotalEnergies (12.5%), Nigerian Agip Exploration (12.5%)Project Status: Final Investment Decision (FID) taken in December 2024Estimated Development Cost: Approximately $5 billionScope of WorkField Development:

body.value:
• Location: Offshore Nigeria, within OML 118, approximately 120 km from the Niger Delta
  • Operator: Shell Nigeria Exploration and Production Company (SNEPCo)
  • Partners: ExxonMobil (20%), TotalEnergies (12.5%), Nigerian Agip Exploration (12.5%)
  • Project Status: Final Investment Decision (FID) taken in December 2024
  • Estimated Development Cost: Approximately $5 billion

Scope of Work

Field Development:

  • Wells: 16 total; comprising 8 production wells and 8 water injection wells
  • Subsea Infrastructure: Installation of risers, flowlines, subsea umbilicals, and other subsea equipment
  • Tie-back: Integration with existing Bonga Main FPSO facility

FPSO Modifications:

  • Upgrades: Modifications to accommodate additional production from Bonga North
  • Capacity: Existing FPSO has a capacity of 225,000 barrels of oil per day

Production Capacity:

  • Peak Oil Production: Up to 110,000 barrels per day
  • Estimated Recoverable Reserves: Over 300 million barrels of oil equivalent (boe)

Project Timeline:

  • First Oil: Expected by the end of the decade (2030)

Contractors:

  • Engineering, Procurement, Construction, and Installation (EPCI): Saipem, KOA Oil & Gas, AVEON Offshore
  • Subsea Production Systems: TechnipFMC

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: Build a 100 km highway connecting Mbour , Fatick and Kaolack in western SenegalThe road will extend the existing highway between Dakar and Mbour for another 100 km, on one of the main axes of the national road network linking Dakar to Mali

body.value:
Build a 100 km highway connecting Mbour , Fatick and Kaolack in western Senegal

The road will extend the existing highway between Dakar and Mbour for another 100 km, on one of the main axes of the national road network linking Dakar to Mali
 

The works include:
- Construction of a 100 km 2x2 lane motorway with: a left side strip (BDG) of 1 metre wide, 2 wide lanes of 3.5 metres each, a strip of emergency stop 3 metres wide, a berm 1 metre wide, a rounded embankment 50 cm wide, a central reservation made up of the two BDGs and a middle strip supporting a DBA type separator with a width of 60 cm;
- Development of 4 interchanges at Thiadiaye, Fatick, Gandiaye and Kaolack;
- Construction of the northern bypass of Kaolack (7 km)
- Installation of 4 toll stations, including 3 on slip roads and 1 on the current section Kaolack, the toll system being compatible with that existing on the current motorway network;
- Construction of 3 large bridges with a total length of 289.6 m;
- Construction of 16 overpasses, 50 underpasses, 210 hydraulic structures; 
- Development of the platform and roads of a service area on either side of the main axis;
- Installation of a suitable fence along the highway on both sides;
- Landscaping;
- Lighting of the exchangers; 1 command centre and video surveillance equipment.
 

The project is connected to the Blaise Diagne International airport (AIBD)-Mbour highway, connecting the special economic zone, AIBD and the eastern regions

The project is part of a system aimed at strengthening the Dakar-Bamako corridor linking to Mali as well as the Dakar-Lagos corridor as part of the wider Praia-Dakar-Abidjan multimodal corridor

The total cost of the project is US$738.7 million, financed by Exim Bank China up to 81.45% and 18.55% by the state of Senegal

body.value:
The current appraisal phase includes the drilling of 4 new appraisal wells with geographical information being used to accurately determine their locations.  These 4 new wells have been drilled and tested with a 250-500m spacing in a square pattern around Serowe 3 well, plus further testing of Serowe 3-1 well.

Downstream Development Concepts

In recognition of the global transition to renewable energy, Botala is developing the following opportunities additional to its main focus on cbm exploration and development:

  • Serowe Energy Hub: proposal for a ~20MW solar/gas hybrid plant to feed electricity into a nearby substation, and
  • Leupane Energy Hub and Industrial Park: proposal for:
    • Leupane Energy Hub: Targeting a 700MW solar/gas hybrid plant near the Morupule power station to feed electricity into the domestic and Southern African Development Community (SADC) networks via the Southern African Power Pool (SAPP), and
    • Leupane Industrial Park: to provide space and services (adjacent to the Leupane Energy Hub) for new-age industries attracted by reliable and affordable energy, its favourable geographic location with access to the SADC markets and its ports for export to Asia and Europe, attractive investment climate, presence of a skilled work force, and access to research facilities.

Source: Botala Energy

attributes.name: title
attributes.content: Serowe CBM Project, Botswana | Project Pipeline

body.value:
Serowe Coal Bed Methane (CBM) Project. 

The Serowe Project near the town of Serowe in the Central District of Botswana consists of ~420,000 hectares of prospecting licenses in the Karoo-Kalahari Basin. Botala has identified an independently certified 2C Resource of 454 billion cubic feet (bcf) in the immediate vicinity of 11 wells drilled within these tenements, and a total prospective resource of more than 7 trillion cubic feet (tcf) within the total area of the Serowe project.  Botala is exploring and developing the cbm potential, aiming to locate high-graded focus areas, or sweet spots, and developing procedures to stimulate cbm flows in commercially attractive volumes.

Exploration has increased the independently certified resource from an initial 23.8bcf 2C (Serowe-1) to 454bcf at the end of Serowe 5.

Since listing on the ASX Botala has completed another 6 exploration wells in the project area, with Serowe 6 and Serowe 7 being completed in early 2023; and Serowe 3-5 being completed in early 2024 bringing the total to 11. Serowe 7 was successfully drilled to the target depth of 510m with logging confirming the presence of gas in 35m of coal intersects within 3 seams. Botala has made the decision to progress with flow testing Serowe 7 and is currently planning surface facilities for flow-testing on site.

Serowe 3 has been showing steady progress with the annulus pressure increasing. Botala has completed drilling 4 new pilot wells around the site of Serowe 3 with core sample testing being conducted in early 2024. A comprehensive geophysical survey over both the Serowe 3 and Serowe 7 areas has been completed as part of the well location selection. This provides Botala with a greater understanding of the presence of coal sections. The site of the Serowe 3 well is location links it to the three main coal seems within the Serowe Area.

  • Well heads and gas gathering network of subsurface pipes connected to the Central Processing Facility within the wellfield for removal of water and impurities.
  • Gas supply to the proposed 20MW gas/solar hybrid pilot in Serowe, currently under advanced planning.
  • Gas being compressed into an export pipeline to the proposed Leupane Energy Hub and Industrial Park.
  • Water disposal from evaporation ponds; a reverse osmosis plant to treat saline water is under consideration.
  • Network of infield pipelines and service tracks.

Source: Botala Energy

Exploration has increased the independently certified resource from an initial 23.8bcf 2C (Serowe-1) to 454bcf at the end of Serowe 5.

Since listing on the ASX Botala has completed another 6 exploration wells in the project area, with Serowe 6 and Serowe 7 being completed in early 2023; and Serowe 3-5 being completed in early 2024 bringing the total to 11. Serowe 7 was successfully drilled to the target depth of 510m with logging confirming the presence of gas in 35m of coal intersects within 3 seams. Botala has made the decision to progress with flow testing Serowe 7 and is currently planning surface facilities for flow-testing on site.

Serowe 3 has been showing steady progress with the annulus pressure increasing. Botala has completed drilling 4 new pilot wells around the site of Serowe 3 with core sample testing being conducted in early 2024. A comprehensive geophysical survey over both the Serowe 3 and Serowe 7 areas has been completed as part of the well location selection. This provides Botala with a greater understanding of the presence of coal sections. The site of the Serowe 3 well is location links it to the three main coal seems within the Serowe Area.

  • Well heads and gas gathering network of subsurface pipes connected to the Central Processing Facility within the wellfield for removal of water and impurities.
  • Gas supply to the proposed 20MW gas/solar hybrid pilot in Serowe, currently under advanced planning.
  • Gas being compressed into an export pipeline to the proposed Leupane Energy Hub and Industrial Park.
  • Water disposal from evaporation ponds; a reverse osmosis plant to treat saline water is under consideration.
  • Network of infield pipelines and service tracks.

Source: Botala Energy

attributes.content: AT-PHOS Phosphoric Acid Plant, Egypt | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: A world-class world-scale significant merchant grade phosphoric acid (MGA) production Project with an annual production capacity of 500,000 MTPY of P2O5.The Complex Facilities will contain two phosphoric acid trains with the associated CIX purification units and one train of Sulfuric acid plant with the associated co-generation plant (Steam Turbines and Electric Generators).

body.value:
A world-class world-scale significant merchant grade phosphoric acid (MGA) production Project with an annual production capacity of 500,000 MTPY of P2O5.

The Complex Facilities will contain two phosphoric acid trains with the associated CIX purification units and one train of Sulfuric acid plant with the associated co-generation plant (Steam Turbines and Electric Generators).

The Project shall be located in the Abu Tartour phosphate mine area in the New Valley Governorate. With a sulfur-burning Sulfuric Acid Plant, the Project shall be energy self-sufficient, fulfilling a significant vertical integration element.

The Project shall be located in the Abu Tartour phosphate mine area in the New Valley Governorate. With a sulfur-burning Sulfuric Acid Plant, the Project shall be energy self-sufficient, fulfilling a significant vertical integration element.

Phosphoric Acid Technology Licensor (Prayon Technologies of Belgium) used their Prayon Di-Hydrate mark IV process to produce filter acid that will be further purified using state of the art continuous Ion-Exchange (CIX) unit. This license has been patented and registered by K-Technologies of USA under the name of MER reduction. Pilot Plant Testing succeeded in producing all kinds of phosphate and compound fertilizers, mainly DAP and MAP.

With the CIX technology, the process can provide flexibility to produce Merchant Grade Acid (MGA) matching any industrial uses. The produced merchant grade phosphoric acid is characterized by the lowest suspended solids, no post precipitations, very low heavy metals content, very low radioactivity.

The Complex Facilities will contain two phosphoric acid trains with the associated CIX purification units and one train of Sulfuric acid plant with the associated co-generation plant (Steam Turbines and Electric Generators). Offsites and utilities have been developed to integrate the overall Project, the basic engineering of which has been done by ENPPI and FLUOR.

Source: Abu Tartour for Phosphoric Acid

attributes.title: Ijora LNG and Propane Terminals, Nigeria

attributes.name: title
attributes.content: Ijora LNG and Propane Terminals, Nigeria | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The Ijora liquefied natural gas (LNG) and propane projects are being developed by Asiko Energy in Ijora, Lagos state, southwestern NigeriaThe projects involve building an LNG storage terminal and a fully mounded propane-rated LPG terminal connected to the Nigerian Pipelines and Storage Company (NPSC) jettiesLNG TerminalThe LNG terminal will be a fully contained in-land storage facility with a 30,000-cubic-metre capacity, 12 vertical tanks and an LNG pipeline

body.value:
The Ijora liquefied natural gas (LNG) and propane projects are being developed by Asiko Energy in Ijora, Lagos state, southwestern Nigeria

The projects involve building an LNG storage terminal and a fully mounded propane-rated LPG terminal connected to the Nigerian Pipelines and Storage Company (NPSC) jetties

LNG Terminal

The LNG terminal will be a fully contained in-land storage facility with a 30,000-cubic-metre capacity, 12 vertical tanks and an LNG pipeline

The shipping infrastructure includes a direct connection to the NPSC jetties through a 12-inch double-walled LNG pipeline to receive gas

The LNG terminal is designed to NFPA 59 standards

Propane Terminal

The propane project involves building a fully-mounded propane-rated terminal for the storage of LPG

The terminal will be connected directly to the NPSC jetties in Apapa through a 10-inch LPG pipeline to receive gas via ship

The terminal will consist of five 1,000MT propane tanks upon completion

 

 

In a June 2024 interview with the Majorwaves Energy Report publication, Felix Ekundayo, managing director and CEO of Asiko Energy said he expected the "LPG propane side" to be fully operational in the next few years as well as the "first phase of [the] LNG terminal"

According to Asiko Energy, the potential of the in-land propane and LNG terminal lies not only in its strategic placement away from traffic dense zones in the Ijora-Apapa axis, but also in its ability to import, store and distribute LPG, accelerate LPG supply across Nigeria and limit LPG scarcity

attributes.name: title
attributes.content: Boundiali Gold Project, Cte dIvoire | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The 1037km2 Boundiali Gold Project in Cte dIvoire is located within the same greenstone belt as Resolutes large Syama (11.5Moz) gold mine and Perseus Sissingu (1.4 Moz) gold mine to the north and Montage Golds 4.5Moz Kon project located to the south. Barricks Tongon mine (5.0Moz) is located to the northeast.

body.value:
The 1037km2 Boundiali Gold Project in Cte dIvoire is located within the same greenstone belt as Resolutes large Syama (11.5Moz) gold mine and Perseus Sissingu (1.4 Moz) gold mine to the north and Montage Golds 4.5Moz Kon project located to the south. Barricks Tongon mine (5.0Moz) is located to the northeast.

In December 2024, Aurum delivered a JORC Mineral Resource of 1.59Moz gold (50.0Mt at 1.0g/t Au) from the BST (Nyangboue), BD Target 1 and 2, and BM Target 1 and 3 deposits at Boundiali. The MRE was based on MRE based on data from 480 drillholes and nearly 74,000m of drilling.

Gold mineralisation remains open along strike and down dip at all deposits. Drilling is ongoing on these deposits, and Aurum has identified other prospects at Boundiali which have yet to be drilled. It plans to drill 100,000m at Boundiali in 2025, with two MRE updates on track and a Pre-Feasibility Study (PFS) to advance the projects development also expected by year end. It has commenced metallurgical test work on samples from the BD deposit.

Background

The Boundiali projects area covers the underexplored southern extension of the Boundiali belt where a highly deformed synclinal greenstone horizon traverses finer grained basin sediments and to the west Tarkwaian clastic rocks lie in contact with a granitic margin.

Historic exploration at PR0893 includes 93 AC drill holes and four RC holes. Airborne geophysical surveying, geological mapping and extensive soil sampling has also been performed at PR0893, while PR0808 has had 91 RC holes drilled for 6,229m along with geochemical analysis and modelling. Detailed geochemical sampling and drilling at PR414 has revealed three strong gold anomalies and returned previous impressive high-grade results (detailed in ASX: AUE 19/03/23).

Source: Aurum Resources

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: Develop the Abaya geothermal prospect located north of Lake Abaya and south of Duguna Fango volcano, within the Wolayita zone of the Southern Nations and Nationalities Peoples Region (SNNPR), about 280 km southwest of Addis AbabaThere is potential to build a 300 MW geothermal power plant with potential for future expansion The area is situated in the southern part of the Ethiopian Rift Valley, which is part of the East African Rift System, and is characterised by high heat flow, indicated by the presence of several hot springs, fumaroles and a geyserFluid ge

body.value:
• Develop the Abaya geothermal prospect located north of Lake Abaya and south of Duguna Fango volcano, within the Wolayita zone of the Southern Nations and Nationalities Peoples Region (SNNPR), about 280 km southwest of Addis Ababa
  • There is potential to build a 300 MW geothermal power plant with potential for future expansion
  • The area is situated in the southern part of the Ethiopian Rift Valley, which is part of the East African Rift System, and is characterised by high heat flow, indicated by the presence of several hot springs, fumaroles and a geyser
  • Fluid geochemistry shows geothermometry of more than 200 degrees Celsius for some hot springs but majority of the hot springs suggest medium temperature geothermal systems. The nature and geological characteristics of the prospect suggests that the geothermal system could be a result of deep circulation through the rift floor faults

attributes.content: Location: Eastern and Central Provinces, ZambiaTotal Length: Approximately 388.8 kilometersGauge: Cape gauge (1,067 mm)Estimated Cost: USD 2.3 billionProject Duration: 4 years (from commencement)Contractor: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), a subsidiary of China Railway Construction Corporation (CRCC)Financing: Initially planned through a loan from the Export-Import Bank of China; however, in March 2020, the Zambian government halted plans to borrow USD 2.03 billion due to concerns over debt sustainability&nb

body.value:
• Location: Eastern and Central Provinces, Zambia
  • Total Length: Approximately 388.8 kilometers
  • Gauge: Cape gauge (1,067 mm)
  • Estimated Cost: USD 2.3 billion
  • Project Duration: 4 years (from commencement)
  • Contractor: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), a subsidiary of China Railway Construction Corporation (CRCC)
  • Financing: Initially planned through a loan from the Export-Import Bank of China; however, in March 2020, the Zambian government halted plans to borrow USD 2.03 billion due to concerns over debt sustainability 

Project Components

Railway Line Construction:

  • Route: From Chipata (Eastern Province) through Petauke to Serenje (Central Province)
  • Length: 388.8 kilometers
  • Track Type: Single-track railway
  • Design Speed:
    • Passenger Trains: Up to 120 km/h
    • Freight Trains: Up to 80 km/h

Stations and Facilities:

  • Stations: Construction of new railway stations at key locations along the route (specific stations to be determined during detailed design)
  • Maintenance Depots: Establishment of maintenance and service facilities for rolling stock and infrastructure

Integration with Existing Networks

Connection Points:

  • Chipata: Integration with the existing ChipataMchinji railway line, facilitating linkage to Malawi and the Nacala Corridor
  • Serenje: Connection to the existing LusakaMpikaNakonde line, part of Zambia's main railway network

Economic and Strategic Significance:

  • Regional Trade Enhancement: The railway is intended to enhance regional and international trade through the Nacala Development Corridor, providing a direct economic stimulus in Zambia, Malawi, and Mozambique
  • Shortest Route to Sea: Once completed, the railway will provide the shortest route of approximately 1,500 kilometers to the sea from Kapiri Mposhi, facilitating access to the Port of Nacala in Mozambique

Financial District

  • 12 mixed-use core and shell buildings
  • Anchored by a commercial plaza

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: Steyn City is a mixed-use luxury estate located in Gauteng, South Africa, covering approximately 2,000 acres of parkland.Key features:

body.value:
Steyn City is a mixed-use luxury estate located in Gauteng, South Africa, covering approximately 2,000 acres of parkland. 

Key features:

  • Clearwater Lagoon Precinct - a 300-meter-long clearwater lagoon serves as a central feature, providing a beach lifestyle experience away from the coast. The lagoon area includes swimming zones, a water park for children, volleyball courts, and a refreshment kiosk.
  • Residential and Mixed-Use Developments - 10,000 residential properties, including apartments, cluster units, and freehold stands.
  • Commercial and Community Facilities - 50,000 m of commercial space, including eight customizable office blocks (Capital Park), AAA-grade offices, and retail centers. Education facilities such as Steyn City School (Grades 000 to matric) and plans for a new college. A retirement village and two retail centers are part of ongoing and future phases.
  • Sports and Recreation - A world-class Jack Nicklaus-designed 18-hole championship golf course. 45 km of floodlit promenades for jogging and walking, a 50 km mountain bike track, resort pools, tennis and pickleball courts, fitness centers, and an equestrian center.

attributes.content: Siloam District Hospital, South Africa | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: Siloam District Hospital, in Vhembe, Limpopo, South Africa, is undergoing a major reconstruction and expansion. The project is being executed in two primary phases:Phase 1: Included the construction of the doctors residence Phase 2: Involves the main hospital complex, renovations, and expansion to include new wards and specialized facilities.The redevelopment encompasses:

body.value:
Siloam District Hospital, in Vhembe, Limpopo, South Africa, is undergoing a major reconstruction and expansion. The project is being executed in two primary phases:

  • Phase 1: Included the construction of the doctors residence
  • Phase 2: Involves the main hospital complex, renovations, and expansion to include new wards and specialized facilities.

The redevelopment encompasses:

  • Construction of new operating theatres, psychiatric, maternity, surgical, and general wards.
  • Replacement of the old gateway clinic and nursing school.
  • Student and staff accommodation.
  • Upgrades to fencing, parking, gatehouse control, landscaping, and associated civil works.
  • Renovation of existing facilities such as the mental ward and mortuary

attributes.title: Egypt-Greece (GREGY) Power Interconnector

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The project involves the construction of a 950 km-long, 500 kV bidirectional submarine cable with a capacity of 3 GW that will directly connect Egypt and mainland Greece (Attica) without intermediate landing pointsThe power to be transferred will come from 9.5 GW of renewable energy projects that will be built and operated in Egypt by Greece's Copelouzos Group

body.value:
• The project involves the construction of a 950 km-long, 500 kV bidirectional submarine cable with a capacity of 3 GW that will directly connect Egypt and mainland Greece (Attica) without intermediate landing points

  • The power to be transferred will come from 9.5 GW of renewable energy projects that will be built and operated in Egypt by Greece's Copelouzos Group 

  • The 4.2 billion (US$4.7 billion) project is being promoted by Elica Mediterranean Electrical Interconnection (Elica), which is a subsidiary of Copelouzos Group

  • About one-third of the power transmitted by the GREGY cable will be consumed in Greece, while one-third will be exported to neighbouring EU countries, with the aim of reducing natural gas consumption by 4.5 billion cubic metres a year

  • Another one-third will be used in Greece for the production of green hydrogen, of which a major portion will be exported to neighbouring EU countries

  • The scheme is set to turn Greece into a clean energy hub in the Eastern Mediterranean region and Southeastern Europe as well as enhance the security of supply in Egypt

  • The project is also in line with the Egyptian governments policy to establish the country as a regional energy hub in the Eastern Mediterranean

  • The GREGY project has been in development since 2008 and was recently included in the EUs list of Projects of Common/Mutual Interest (PCI/PMI). It is also an EU Global Gateway flagship infrastructure scheme

  • The scheme is seeing increased impetus following the EUs decision to fully end its dependency on Russian energy

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The whole township is known as Goudrand Ext 4 and it will be subdivided into 15 different phases to be known as Goudrand Ext 5 to 19. The proposed Goudrand Ext 4 development is an integrated development consisting of 13,000 plus potential housing opportunities.

body.value:
The whole township is known as Goudrand Ext 4 and it will be subdivided into 15 different phases to be known as Goudrand Ext 5 to 19. The proposed Goudrand Ext 4 development is an integrated development consisting of 13,000 plus potential housing opportunities.

The first phase of the development is a mixed use project comprising of 13,197 housing opportunities in a mix of 1 204 Residential 1 bonded units, 1,325 Residential 1 FLISP units, 10,668 Residential 3 units, 5 educational sites, 3 shopping centre sites, and 7 crche sites, 8 worship sites, a hospital site, a cemetery and municipal sites.

The proposed units will comply with the current norms and standards of the Gauteng Department of Human Settlements. The FLISP houses will be freehold houses and 3-Storey walk-up sectional title units while the BNG units will be built as duplex units consisting of a living/kitchen area and bathroom on ground floor and two bedrooms upstairs and single units in 3-storey blocks.

Source: Gauteng Department of Human Settlements

attributes.content: Maitland Metro, South Africa | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The precinct will feature residential apartments, recreational facilities, green parks and commercial and retail opportunities.The upgraded public realm and urban spaces will incorporate a landscaping and greening component, a public plaza on Camp Road, and extensive greened pedestrian walkways. A park will be developed under the M5 flyover to activate this neglected space and host a variety of recreational activities such as netball, basketball, five-a-side soccer, and outdoor chess.

body.value:
The precinct will feature residential apartments, recreational facilities, green parks and commercial and retail opportunities. 

The upgraded public realm and urban spaces will incorporate a landscaping and greening component, a public plaza on Camp Road, and extensive greened pedestrian walkways. A park will be developed under the M5 flyover to activate this neglected space and host a variety of recreational activities such as netball, basketball, five-a-side soccer, and outdoor chess.

In partnership with the City of Cape Town, play infrastructure, street furniture and lighting will be incorporated to make these public spaces safe and usable, together with large feature trees for shade.

Residential

The development of well-designed, well-built residential apartment blocks is the most significant aspect of the Maitland Metro urban regeneration project. Over the next five years, more than 1,200 new residential units will be added to the precinct in at least seven new mixed-use projects.

Commercial

Maitland Metro will deliver over 50,000 m of mixed-use with over 15,000 m of commercial space in seven new buildings.

attributes.content: Riverfields Lifestyle Precinct, South Africa | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: Location: Ekurhuleni, GautengTotal Area: 1,500 hectaresProject Type: Mixed-use precinct  residential, logistics, commercialProject DescriptionThe Riverfields Lifestyle Precinct is a major mixed-use development located on a 1,500-hectare site in Gauteng, South Africa. Designed as a strategic urban node, the precinct integrates residential, commercial, and logistics functions to serve the growing demands of the Johannesburg and OR Tambo International Airport corridor.

body.value:
• Location: Ekurhuleni, Gauteng
  • Total Area: 1,500 hectares
  • Project Type: Mixed-use precinct residential, logistics, commercial

Project Description

The Riverfields Lifestyle Precinct is a major mixed-use development located on a 1,500-hectare site in Gauteng, South Africa. Designed as a strategic urban node, the precinct integrates residential, commercial, and logistics functions to serve the growing demands of the Johannesburg and OR Tambo International Airport corridor.

The precinct is anchored by its logistics and distribution platform, with 255,000 square metres of logistics facilities currently under construction, and an additional 450,000 square metres planned for future development. Riverfields is a key hub for regional supply chain and warehousing infrastructure.

Scope of Work

Residential Development:

  • Over 1,000 completed housing units, valued at approximately R2 billion
  • 400 additional homes under construction
  • 1,000 more units in the planning pipeline
  • Includes multiple secure residential estates within the precinct

Logistics & Industrial:

  • 255,000 m of logistics and distribution centres under active construction
  • Future development pipeline of 450,000 m of logistics facilities

Commercial & Mixed Use (Planned/Proposed):

  • Precinct to incorporate retail centres, schools, office space, and public amenities
  • Integrated road and utility infrastructure to support growth

body.value:
The Leeuwpoort Housing Project, also known as the Leeuwpoort Mega Project or Leeuwpoort Integrated Housing Development, is a large-scale, mixed-use residential development located in Boksburg, within the Ekurhuleni Metropolitan Municipality, Gauteng, South Africa. 

The development is situated on approximately 7691,300 hectares of land and is expected to deliver up to 24,000 residential units.

The development includes:

  • Residential (various densities and subsidy types)
  • Retail and commercial facilities
  • Schools (primary and secondary)
  • Clinics and healthcare facilities
  • Community and social facilities
  • Public open spaces and parks
  • Transportation infrastructure (railway, taxi rank)
  • Retirement village and serviced stands

attributes.name: title
attributes.content: Abu Rawash Waste-to-Energy Project, Egypt | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: Project DescriptionGreen Tech Egypt, in partnership with OAK Holding and the Ministry of Military Production, is undertaking a large-scale Waste-to-Energy (WTE) project valued at USD 500 million. The project is a key component of Egypts renewable energy strategy and aligns with Egypt Vision 2023.

body.value:
Project Description

Green Tech Egypt, in partnership with OAK Holding and the Ministry of Military Production, is undertaking a large-scale Waste-to-Energy (WTE) project valued at USD 500 million. The project is a key component of Egypts renewable energy strategy and aligns with Egypt Vision 2023.

Over three phases, the plant will process 1.8 million tons of municipal solid waste annually, beginning with a Phase 1 capacity of over 450,000 tons/year, generating 30 megawatts (MW) of electricity. The facility will comply with both Egyptian and European environmental standards, ensuring sustainable waste management and clean energy production.

The project also supports national goals of industrial development, job creation, and capacity building by utilizing the facilities of the National Organization for Military Production (NOMP) and involving local Egyptian companies in its execution. It will provide training opportunities for graduate students, contributing to workforce development in Egypts emerging waste-to-energy sector.

  • Project Partners: Green Tech Egypt, OAK Holding, Ministry of Military Production (MoMP)
  • Project Value: USD 500 million
  • Phasing: 3 Phases
  • Annual Waste Processing Capacity (Full): 1.8 million tons
  • Phase 1 Capacity: 450,000 tons/year
  • Power Generation (Phase 1): 30 MW

Scope of Work

Phase 1 Development:

  • Processing capacity: over 450,000 tons/year of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW)
  • Electricity generation: 30 MW
  • Compliance with Egyptian and EU environmental standards

Future Phases:

  • Gradual expansion to 1.8 million tons/year processing capacity
  • Incremental increase in energy output to match processing growth

Plant Infrastructure

  • Waste reception and sorting facilities
  • Waste combustion or thermal treatment systems
  • Energy recovery systems and grid connection infrastructure
  • Environmental control systems (air emissions, residue handling)

attributes.name: title
attributes.content: Indorama Fertilizer Line 3, Nigeria | Project Pipeline

body.value:
Indorama Eleme Fertilizer III

Known as Line 3 in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. Line 3 is designed to build upon the technologies and knowledge gained from the development and operation of Line 1 and Line 2, featuring similar technology and capacity. The creation of Line 3 will raise the present urea production capacity from 2.8 MMTPA to 4.2 MMTPA. The Line 3 plant will contain a 2,300 Metric Tons Per Day (MTPD) capacity for ammonia, a 4,000 MTPD urea facility, steam, cooling tower, water treatment, product handling, power, nitrogen, plant air and instrument air, passive and active firefighting systems, along with product storage and material handling facilities.

In addition, the expansion of production facilities will result in an estimated surplus of 400 MTPD of ammonia. To facilitate exports of fertilizer and ammonia, the project also encompasses the construction of a dedicated jetty, named Line 3 Jetty. Positioned approximately 20 kilometers from the production site, at the Onne Port Complex, this planned jetty will expand Indoramas existing export infrastructure capacity by providing necessary storage and export capabilities for the surplus ammonia and bulk urea produced by Line 3.

The Indorama complex, the site of the Line 3 implementation, features state-of-the-art facilities such as a captive gas fired power unit, utilities, an effluent treatment plant, storage tanks, bagging, a warehouse, and other supporting facilities.

The projected construction cost of Line 3 and the Line 3 Jetty is US$1.250 billion. The proposed construction period is three years for Line 3, and two years for the jetty.

Source: International Finance Corporation. Reference: Project Number
47723

body.value:
The Niger Accelerating Electricity Access Project, known as "Hask" (meaning "light" in Hausa), is a major government initiative supported by the World Bank to rapidly increase electricity access across Niger. The project aims to raise the national electricity access rate to 30% by 2026 and 80% by 2035, addressing both urban and rural electrification challenges.

Scope

Reinforcement and Expansion of Transmission and Distribution Networks:

  • Construction of a 270 km double circuit 132-kV line (or a single circuit 330-kV line) and 3-4 substations connecting Zabori (Zone Fleuve) to Malbaza (Niger Centre-Est) via Doutchi and Konni.
  • Upgrading and densifying existing distribution networks, and building new medium and low voltage networks to electrify new localities, especially rural development hubs.

Deployment of Solar Mini-Grids and Off-Grid Solutions:

  • Building new mini-grids and adding solar systems to existing mini-thermal power plants in rural areas.
  • Providing electricity to households, public facilities (health centers, schools, water boreholes), and promoting productive use for businesses.

Source: World Bank - Source ID P174034

attributes.title: Lake Kariba Floating Solar Plant, Zimbabwe

attributes.name: title
attributes.content: Lake Kariba Floating Solar Plant, Zimbabwe | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The Intensive Energy Users Group (IEUG) has proposed the development of a 1,000 MW solar power station to be floated on Lake Kariba and to augment the power generated by the water-driven turbines at the dam wall of the Kariba South Hydropower StationThis proposal has been accepted by the Zambezi River Authority (ZRA), the Zimbabwe Government and the power utility that runs the turbines at the wall  the Zimbabwe Power Corporation (ZPC)

body.value:
The Intensive Energy Users Group (IEUG) has proposed the development of a 1,000 MW solar power station to be floated on Lake Kariba and to augment the power generated by the water-driven turbines at the dam wall of the Kariba South Hydropower Station

This proposal has been accepted by the Zambezi River Authority (ZRA), the Zimbabwe Government and the power utility that runs the turbines at the wall the Zimbabwe Power Corporation (ZPC)

The project is being divided into four stages of 250 MW each. It will involve installing 420,000 solar panels on a floating platform in a sheltered bay some 15 km from the main power plant. This will feed energy via a control system to a major battery complex where the energy will be stored prior to delivery to the ZPC power plant.. Here, it will be blended with hydropower and fed into the national grid via transmission lines to the north and south

When all stages are complete, the solar platform will increase the overall capacity of the hydroelectric plant by a third and reduce water use to a level that is more manageable. The batteries used will help stabilise and manage the power generated and allow ZPC to control the flow of energy generated to the grid. It will do so at a cost that is well below the cost of conventional power stations. This incremental power will be sold to IEUG members as baseload power for mining and industrial production

The study to determine viability and technical details was to start in January 2025 over a period of five months at a cost of US$4.5 million, conducted by a team of consultants from China, Germany, Britain, South Africa and Zimbabwe. Once completed, the study will be employed to secure the funding required to cover the cost of the project. 

The project is being backed by the African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank), which is putting up US$3 million for the bankable study, with IEUG putting up the additional US$1.5 million

 

(Source: IEUG)

body.value:
Also known as Raville Compound project in the Fifth Settlement, Cairo, Egypt

Project Overview

Raville Compound is a large-scale, mixed-use urban development located in Fifth Settlement, Cairo. The project combines residential, commercial, hospitality, and public service functions, with a distinctive architectural landmark in the form of Raville Tower. The development aims to integrate modern living with cultural symbolism and high-quality urban infrastructure.

Notable Architectural Feature

Raville Tower: A symbolic high-rise structure inspired by ancient Egyptian architecture. Designed as a pharaonic obelisk crowned with a pyramid entrance, it serves as the centerpiece of the compound and covers a vast footprint of over 5.48 million square meters.

Key Project Components

Residential Zone

  • Standard Housing Buildings (870,074 m)
  • Distinguished Housing Buildings (343,982 m)
  • Twin and Town Villas Area (202,252 m)
  • Separate Villas (149,734 m)

Public Services and Community Facilities

  • Public Services Area (36,421 m)
  • Mass Transit Station
  • Places of Worship
  • Utilities and Facilities Zone
  • Medical Complex (part of 161,874 m total)

Commercial, Business, and Entertainment Zone

  • Financial and Business District
  • Shopping Centers
  • Multi-purpose Commercial Areas
  • Entertainment Areas
  • Total commercial and entertainment area: 313,631 m

Hospitality and Hotel Zone

  • Hotel Area (178,061 m)

Landmark Feature

  • Raville Tower
    • Architectural Design (Pharaonic Obelisk with Pyramid Entrance)
    • Structural Works
    • MEP and Interior Finishing
    • Total landmark development area: 5,483,490 m

body.value:
Dose is a major luxury resort and residential project located on Egypts North Coast on the Alexandria-Marsa Matrouh road, near El Dabaa.

The project covers approximately 125 acres, with 70% of the area dedicated to green spaces and water features, including artificial lakes and landscaped parks. Dose offers a wide range of property types, including apartments, chalets, villas, townhouses, and twin houses, with unit sizes starting from around 70 square meters.

Dose is designed as a fully integrated, entertainment-focused community, including:

  • Multiple swimming pools and artificial lakes
  • Sports facilities (gym, running and cycle tracks)
  • Childrens play areas
  • Spa and wellness centers
  • Cafes and restaurants

attributes.content: BumbaAketiButaMungbere Railway Rehabilitation, DRC | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The BumbaAketiButaMungbere (also known as Uls-Rivers) Railway Line Rehabilitation and Modernization project is a strategic infrastructure initiative aimed at restoring and upgrading a critical rail corridor in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Originally constructed between 1924 and 1937, this historic railway line spans several hundred kilometers across the Mongala and Ul provinces, connecting the river port city of Bumba to the eastern town of Mungbere via Aketi and Buta.

body.value:
The BumbaAketiButaMungbere (also known as Uls-Rivers) Railway Line Rehabilitation and Modernization project is a strategic infrastructure initiative aimed at restoring and upgrading a critical rail corridor in the northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Originally constructed between 1924 and 1937, this historic railway line spans several hundred kilometers across the Mongala and Ul provinces, connecting the river port city of Bumba to the eastern town of Mungbere via Aketi and Buta. The railway was once vital for transporting agricultural produce, minerals, and passengers but has been largely non-operational due to decades of neglect and conflict-related damage.

This project seeks to rehabilitate and modernize the railway infrastructure to facilitate efficient, safe, and sustainable rail transport. Key activities include comprehensive track repairs, upgrading signaling and telecommunications systems, and implementing modern operating standards. The rehabilitation will improve domestic rail connectivity, foster economic development by opening up the eastern regions rich in natural resources, and support the integration of the DRCs transport network.

The initiative is guided by the DRC governments Ministry of Transport and Communication Routes, which has issued an international call for expressions of interest from qualified partners. The project aims to attract experienced rail operators and investors to ensure long-term sustainability and operational excellence. Ultimately, the revitalized railway will enhance regional trade, provide reliable freight and passenger services, and contribute to socio-economic growth in a region historically underserved by transport infrastructure.

attributes.content: Kigali Informal Settlement Upgrading, Rwanda | Project Pipeline

attributes.name: description
attributes.content: The Kigali Informal Settlement Upgrading Project (KISUP) is a large-scale initiative to transform informal settlements into safer, healthier, and more resilient neighborhoods, while preserving community ties and promoting inclusive urban development. The project targets neighborhoods such as Kagugu, Rwezamenyo, and Nyakabanda.Key Features:

body.value:
The Kigali Informal Settlement Upgrading Project (KISUP) is a large-scale initiative to transform informal settlements into safer, healthier, and more resilient neighborhoods, while preserving community ties and promoting inclusive urban development. The project targets neighborhoods such as Kagugu, Rwezamenyo, and Nyakabanda.

Key Features:

  • Roads and Utilities: Upgrades include new access roads, footpaths, stormwater drainage systems, improved water supply networks, and street lighting.
  • Social Facilities: The project will deliver new or improved schools, health posts, markets, recreational areas, green spaces, community halls, early childhood development centers, sports grounds, and libraries.
  • Housing: Residents will have the opportunity to upgrade their homes without displacement, with a focus on affordable rental housing to minimize gentrification risk
